questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is diagnosed with leukemia and begins chemotherapy in preparation for a bone marrow transplant. Two months later, gross hematuria develops, and the patient begins to complain of occasional incontinence. It is determined that these symptoms are caused by one of her chemotherapeutic agents. Coadministration of what medication might have prevented the patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mesna The patient is experiencing hemorrhagic cystitis, a well-known complication of cyclophosphamide treatment. Cyclophosphamide produces a metabolite known as acrolein, which is toxic to the bladder epithelium and can lead to hemorrhagic cystitis. Coadministration of mesna with cyclophosphamide can prevent hemorrhagic cystitis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . is not correct: Fomepizole , an inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, is an antidote for methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning. Option: B. is not correct: Leucovorin is a folinic acid supplement used in the prevention or treatment of an overdose of dihydrofolate reductase inhibitors such as methotrexate or trimethoprim. Option: D. is not correct: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analog that increases secretion of the gastric mucous barrier. It is used in the prevention of NSAID-induced peptic ulcers. It is not used to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis

Extraedge:

Hemorrhagic cystitis: This form of cystitis follows radiation injury or antitumor chemotherapy (cyclophosphamide). Adenovirus infection also causes a hemorrhagic cystitis. Characterized by marked hemorrhage and ulcerations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to a urologic oncologist with a painless, solid testicular mass. A diagnostic evaluation including scrotal ultrasound, radiographic studies, serum markers, and positron emission tomography scan is performed. The patient is diagnosed with low-risk disseminated seminoma. The physician tells the patient that the standard treatment is three cycles of a combination of etoposide, cisplatin, and a third agent that can cause pulmonary fibrosis. What is the mechanism of action of this third agent?

options.label: B
options.text: Generation of free radicals that cause single dsDNA breaks

questions.correct_answer: B. Generation of free radicals that cause single dsDNA breaks
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Generation of free radicals that cause single dsDNA breaks Bleomycin is a part of the BEP regimen for treating testicular cancer (bleomycin, etoposide, and cisplatin). It is also used in the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma. It is an antineoplastic antibiotic that halts cell division by generating free radicals that cause single double-stranded DNA breaks. The major adverse reactions are pulmonary fibrosis and hyperpigmentation. Although busulfan, an alkylating agent, can also cause pulmonary fibrosis, it is more commonly used for the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option:A is not correct: 6-Mercaptopurine (6-MP) works by blocking de novo purine synthesis. Common adverse effects include bone marrow suppression and gastrointestinal or liver toxicity. Option:C is not correct: Cytarabine , in the treatment of acute myelogenous leukemia. It halts cell division by inhibiting DNA polymerase. Adverse reactions include leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and megaloblastic anemia. Option:D is not correct: Etoposide is an s-and phase-specific topoisomerase II inhibitor commonly used to treat small cell carcinoma and testicular cancer. Major adverse effects include myelosuppression.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of breast cancer that was successfully treated with trastuzumab 3 years prior now returns with a breast lump she palpated on self-exam. After imaging and biopsy, it is determined that the cancer has returned. You decide to begin her on trastuzumab therapy once again; however, her returning cancer is now unresponsive to this drug. Which of the following is a possible mechanism responsible for the chemotherapy resistance in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased tumor expression of the bcl-2 proto-oncogene

options.label: C
options.text: Increased drug excretion through the kidneys

options.label: D
options.text: Tumor cell alteration of drug target

questions.correct_answer: D. Tumor cell alteration of drug target
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tumor cell alteration of drug target Cancer cells acquire many mutations as time progresses because of their inherent genomic instability. Similar to bacteria acquiring resistance to antibiotics, chemotherapies can kill all susceptible cells and leave only cells that have acquired mutations to chemotherapy targets, thus making the drug ineffective. This patient’s tumor has developed acquired resistance to trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody that acts against the cell surface HER2 receptor.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. is not correct: Many chemotherapy drugs are inactive in their native state and must be covalently modified to become active. In decreasing the rates at which drugs are activated, cancer cells effectively decrease active drug concentration. Option: B . is not correct: Chemoresistance has been associated with increased expression of the bcl-2 oncogene. Option: C . is not correct: Unless cancer involves the kidneys, there is no evidence that cancers can affect the rate at which the kidneys excrete various drugs.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who recently emigrated from Southeast Asia comes to her physician’s office with uterine enlargement, a vaginal mass, and vaginal bleeding. A biopsy of the vaginal mass yields A diagnosis of choriocarcinoma, and the patient is started on the usual therapeutic agent for this condition. After several weeks of therapy, the patient develops mild icterus; an enlarged, red, painful tongue; and sores in the corners of the mouth. Her complete blood cell count returns: WBCs: 2000/mm3 Hemoglobin: 9.0 g/dl Hematocrit: 26.4% Platelets: 90,000/mm3 Which of the following would most likely treat her abnormal cell count?

options.label: D
options.text: Administration of increased doses of the chemotherapy agent

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Administration of folinic acid This patient has mucositis, glossitis, and myelosuppression secondary to methotrexate treatment. Methotrexate is a folate analog that acts by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, which is responsible for converting folic acid to tetrahydrofolic acid. Tetrahydrofolic acid is responsible for the synthesis of several amino acids, purines, and thymidine, a required molecule for DNA synthesis. By inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, methotrexate induces a deficiency of tetrahydrofolic acid in the setting of normal folate levels. Methotrexate toxicity must therefore be treated by providing reduced folate (folinic acid, also known as leucovorin) rather than folic acid, known as a “leucovorin rescue.”

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option:A. is not correct: Erythropoietin is a hormone that stimulates RBC production in the bone marrow. Erythropoietin is used to treat anemia secondary to chronic kidney disease and myelodysplasia from chemoradiation treatment. It cannot, however, correct anemia secondary to methotrexate because methotrexate causes deficiencies in DNA precursors so the body is unable to make new cells. Option:B. is not correct: Folic acid is useful only in dietary folic acid deficiency, not deficiency induced by methotrexate. Methotrexate can cause myelosuppression, even with normal levels of folic acid, because it inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase that converts folic acid into its active metabolite, tetrahydrofolate. Option:D. is not correct: The treatment for choriocarcinoma is methotrexate. Increasing methotrexate doses would only exacerbate this patient's megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male patient who is being treated for acute lymphoblastic T-cell lymphoma begins to experience severe flank pain, dysuria, vomiting, and altered mental status 5 days after the initiation of chemotherapy. Laboratory studies show the following, with normal values for a 10-year-old male in parentheses: Serum Na+: 144 mEq/L (135-145 mEq/L) Serum K+: 5.6 mEq/L (3.6-5.2 mEq/L) Serum Ca2+: 9.2 mEq/L (8.7-10.3 mg/dL) Serum phosphorus: 6.5 mg/dl (3.0-6.0 mg/dL) Serum uric acid: 7.9 mg/dl (2.0-5.5 mg/dL) Which of the following drugs is most appropriate as prophylaxis for this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Allopurinol Lysis of tumor cells following chemotherapy results in the release of potassium, uric acid, and phosphorus, leading to hyperkalemia, hyperuricemia, and hyperphosphatemia with secondary hypocalcemia. These metabolic abnormalities can then lead to renal failure and possibly multiple organ failure and death. This syndrome can be prevented with aggressive intravenous hydration and the administration of allopurinol. Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that reduces uric acid production. Keep in mind that normal uric acid levels in children are lower than those for adults (2.0-5.5 mg/dL.) Uric acid production increases dramatically during puberty, and males reach adult uric acid levels between the ages of 12 and 14. Therefore, it is possible for a preadolescent child suffering from tumor lysis syndrome to have a uric acid level less than that of a normal adult.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. is not correct: Amlodipine is an antihypertensive medication used to treat angina. It acts as a long-acting calcium channel blocker and relaxes the smooth muscle in the arterial wall, thereby decreasing total peripheral resistance. Amlodipine does not help prevent and is not used to treat tumor lysis syndrome. Option: C . is not correct: Colchicine is primarily used to treat acute gout flares in patients who have intolerance or contraindication to therapy with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. It acts by binding to tubulin and inhibiting microtubule formation, thereby preventing neutrophil migration and cell division. Diarrhea, abdominal cramping, nausea, and vomiting are classic side effects. Colchicine is not used to treat tumor lysis syndrome. Option: D . is not correct: Losartan is used to treat high blood pressure, not tumor lysis syndrome, and acts as an angiotensin II receptor antagonist.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a 40-pack-year history of smoking presents with weakness, fatigue, and cough. Laboratory studies show hypokalemic alkalosis without a history of vomiting or diarrhea. Levels of cortisol and ACTH are found to be high in both plasma and urine, which are unaffected by either administration of high-dose dexamethasone or corticotropin-releasing hormone. An MRI of the chest shows an unresectable centrally located lung mass. Which of the following is the best available medical treatment to prevent the development of centripetal obesity and moon facies in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ketoconazole Ketoconazole is an antifungal agent that is used to treat systemic fungal infections by inhibiting fungal 14-a-demethylase. Furthermore, in patients with ectopic ACTH-secreting tumors (the most common of which is small cell lung cancer), ketoconazole or metyrapone can be used to inhibit ACTH effects and thus mitigate the progression to a Cushingoid appearance. Ketoconazole does this by inhibiting human 11-~-hydroxylase, which reduces adrenal production of cortisol in response to ACTH.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. is not correct: Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that functions by blocking epithelial sodium channels in the late distal collecting tubule (DCT) and collecting duct to inhibit sodium reabsorption from the lumen. Unlike spironolactone (which also acts on the DCT and collecting duct), it does not have potent anti-androgen effects. Amiloride is not used to treat the paraneoplastic hypercortisolism described in this patient. Option: B. is not correct: Desmopressin acetate (DDAVP) is a synthetic analog of ADH. Desmopressin binds to V2 receptors in renal collecting ducts, increasing water resorption. This property makes it an effective treatment for diabetes insipidus. Desmopressin would not affect ACTH secretion. Option: C. is not correct: Finasteride decreases the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone and is useful in the treatment of benign prostatic hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a large lump in his right testicle. Both serum a-fetoprotein and 13-human chorionic gonadotropin are elevated, and ultrasound of the testicle suggests a malignancy. The mass is resected and a retroperitoneal lymph node dissection is performed, which reveals significant nodal spread. The patient is started on adjuvant chemotherapy, but after several months develops dyspnea. Chest x-ray demonstrates ground-glass opacities. Which chemotherapeutic agent could have contributed to this adverse effect?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bleomycin Bleomycin inhibits DNA synthesis by binding to DNA and causing single-strand and double-strand breaks. An adverse effect of bleomycin is pulmonary fibrosis

Highyeild:

Antibiotics. Bleomycin: Mechanism: The drug has its greatest effect on neoplastic cell in the G2 phase of the cell replication cycle. Although bleomycin intercalates DNA, the major cytotoxicity is believed to result from ironcatalyzed free radical formation and DNA strand breakage. Indications It is useful in Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, testicular cancer, and several other solid tumors. Adverse Effects: Bleomycin produces very little myelosuppression. The most serious toxicities of Bleomycin are pulmonary and mucocutaneous reactions.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. is not correct: Cisplatin is an anti-neoplastic drug used in the treatment of testicular cancer . Common adverse effects include nephrotoxicity and acoustic nerve damage, but not pulmonary fibrosis . Option: C . is not correct: Dactinomycin is an antibiotic with anti-cancer effects. It works by intercalating into the DNA and blocking RNA polymerase . Its main dose-limiting toxicity is bone marrow suppression , not pulmonary fibrosis. Option: D . is not correct: Imatinib is a tyrosine kinas e inhibitor used in the treatment of chronic myelocytic leukemia and gastrointestinal stromal tumors. The most common adverse effect is fluid retention, not pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with non-Hodgkin lymphoma has been undergoing treatment with cyclophosphamide for the past 4 months. At his biweekly visit, he tells his doctor that for the past day or so, he has noticed a reddish tinge in his urine. In addition, he has a moderate amount of pain in the suprapubic region and complains of burning when he urinates. The physician suspects a potentially dangerous drug-related complication. What is the mechanism of the drug that is commonly given to combat this likely complication?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Binding of toxic metabolites Hemorrhagic cystitis is a serious condition that occurs in cancer patients due to radiation, chemotherapy, and infections. It is characterized by diffuse mucosal inflammation and hemorrhage of the entire bladder. Chemotherapeutic drugs can cause hemorrhagic cystitis when they are directly infused into the bladder for superficial bladder cancers or when excreted drugs contact the bladder epithelium. The alkylating agent 'cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide are the chemotherapeutic agents most likely to cause hemorrhagic cystitis. The condition is a result of the renal excretion of acrolein, a hepatic metabolite of these drugs. Mesna is a sulfhydryl compound that is an effective neuroprotective agent for patients undergoing treatment with either cyclophosphamide or ifosfamide.

Highyeild:

Adverse Effects of Alkylating Agents Myelosuppression is the dose-limiting adverse effect for alkylating agents. Nausea and vomiting are common as are teratogenesis and gonadal atrophy, although in the latter cases these are variable, according to the drug, its schedule, and route of administration. Treatment also carries a major risk of leukemogenesis and carcinogenesis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. is not correct: Ifosfamide is an alkylating agent similar to cyclophosphamide and thus can cause hemorrhagic cystitis. Option: C. is not correct: Leucovorin , or folinic acid, is used as a “rescue” agent to reverse the myelosuppression caused by treatment with methotrexate. It is not effective in reversing myelosuppression caused by 5-fluorouracil and does not have any utility in treating or preventing hemorrhagic cystitis. Option: D. is not correct: Cimetidine is a histamine (H2)-receptor blocker used as prophylaxis against and treatment for peptic ulcers, gastritis, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. It is not used to treat or prevent hemorrhagic cystitis

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents with a 1-week history of slurred speech and gait disturbances. Her medical history is significant for coronary artery disease and chronic kidney disease. She is a retired schoolteacher and has a 50-pack-year smoking history. CT of the chest reveals a 4-cm lung mass and mediastinal adenopathy. Laboratory tests show elevated anti-Hu and anti-Yo antibody levels. The patient is admitted to the hospital and started on combination therapy with a platinum agent and etoposide. What is the mechanism of action of etoposide?

options.label: B
options.text: The covalent intersternal linkage of DNA leads to DNA inactivation

options.label: C
options.text: The direct inhibition of anaphase through stabilizing polymerized microtubules

options.label: D
options.text: The inhibition of topoisomerase II, leading to increased DNA degradation

questions.correct_answer: D. The inhibition of topoisomerase II, leading to increased DNA degradation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The inhibition of topoisomerase II, leading to increased DNA degradation This patient is presenting with a paraneoplastic syndrome, evidenced by her neurologic symptoms and anti-Hu and anti-Yo antibodies, in association with small cell lung cancer (SCLC). These autoantibodies have been associated with an encephalomyelitis with a diverse array of presenting features that include slurred speech and gait anomalies. Her smoking history puts her at risk for SCLC. Treatment for SCLC involves a platinum agent such as carboplatin or cisplatin in combination with etoposide. The stabilization of the topoisomerase II-DNA complex during the S and G2 phases of the cell cycle by etoposide results in the induction of double-stranded DNA breaks and prevents the completion of the G2 phase. Side effects of etoposide include bone marrow suppression, alopecia, and nausea and vomiting.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. is not correct: The prevention of progression through the cell cycle by etoposide causes cells to undergo apoptosis rather than necrosis. Option: B. is not correct: Alkylating agents such as cyclophosphamide cause covalent intersternal linkages of DNA that consequently inactivate the DNA. Option: C. is not correct: Some chemotherapy treatments such as paclitaxel hyperstabilize polymerized microtubules so that the mitotic spindles cannot break down. Thus, this type of anticancer drug directly prevents anaphase from occurring.

Table:

Type I Topoisomerase enzymes binds to a DNA molecule, it cuts one strand, simultaneously generating a covalent phosphoester bond between the released 5' phosphate on the DNA & a tyrosine residue in the enzyme Formation of phosphotyrosine bond does not require ATP or another source of energy. The free 3'-hydroxyl end of the DNA is held noncovalently by the enzyme. The DNA strand that has not been cleaved is then passed through the single-stranded break. The cleaved strand is then resealed & thus removes negative supercoils.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman is diagnosed with stage IIA breast cancer and subsequently has a 3-cm tumor surgically removed. No lymph nodes are found to be positive during dissection. Because her tumor was estrogen receptor positive, her oncologist decides to prescribe a specific long-term oral chemotherapeutic medication to help prevent recurrence or relapse. What is a potential adverse effect of the medication most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hot flashes Since the patient’s tumor is ER-positive , raloxifene or tamoxifen were likely prescribed. These drugs are selective estrogen receptor modulators ( SERM s) that bind the estrogen receptor and have both agonist and antagonist activit y, depending upon the tissue. Both drugs are antagonists at the breasts, which helps prevent the growth, survival, and division of ER-positive cancer cells , thereby preventing recurrenc The mechanism by which these drugs cause hot flashes is due to their antagonistic effect s. Estrogen withdrawal at the level of the hypothalamus results in thermoregulatory dysfunction and subsequent temperature dysregulation.

Partial estrogen agonists have no significant effects on the GI system; they commonly cause hot flashes in postmenopausal women. Option: C . is not correct: This is an adverse effect of sildenafil and vardenafil , but not of selective estrogen receptor modulators. These drugs are used to treat erectile dysfunction and some cases of pulmonary hypertension through the prevention of cGMP degradation by PDES in the corpus cavernosum, thus leading to smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation. Option: D. is not correct: Neutropenia , or low neutrophil count, is a common adverse effect of many chemotherapeutic agents used to treat breast cancer and other cancer types due to the toxic effect of these treatments on the bone marrow .

questions.text: Alkalinization of urine ameliorates the toxicity of which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methotrexate Alkalinization of urine speeds the clearance of weakly acidic drugs e.g. aspirin, Phenobarbital, chlorpropamide, and Methotrexate, etc.

Highyeild:

Interaction involving excretion is important mostly in the case of drugs actively secreted by tubular transport mechanisms, e.g. probenecid inhibits tubular secretion of penicillins and cephalosporins and prolongs their plasma t½. This is particularly utilized in the single-dose treatment of gonorrhea. Aspirin blocks the uricosuric action of probenecid and decreases tubular secretion of methotrexate. Change in the pH of urine can also affect the excretion of weakly acidic or weakly basic drugs. This has been utilized in the treatment of poisonings. Diuretics and to some extent tetracyclines, ACE inhibitors, and certain NSAIDs have been found to raise steady-state blood levels of lithium by promoting its tubular reabsorption.

questions.text: A patient with Wilms’ tumor is receiving a chemotherapeutic agent that is described as working by intercalating into DNA strands, and that is efficacious regardless of which stage of the cell cycle the tumor cells are in. Which of the following agents best fits this description?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dactinomycin (actinomycin D) Dactinomycin is used to treat some kinds of cancer that affect the testicles (testicular cancer), uterus, or womb (gestational trophoblastic neoplasia), kidneys (Wilms' tumor), bones and muscles (Ewing's sarcoma).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: C. Dactinomycin intercalates between and eventually binds to DNA base pairs. This distortion of the DNA chains makes the DNA an unsuitable template for RNA polymerase, and ultimately RNA and protein synthesis is inhibited. Dactinomycin is cell cycle-nonspecific. It is the drug of choice for Wilm’s tumor and is the 2nd drug for ectopic pregnancy. Option : A. Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor. This is an oral agent used for postmenopausal women with early or advanced breast cancer. In postmenopausal women, the major source of estrogen (which supports the growth and replication of estrogen-dependent tumors) is androgens. Those androgens are metabolized by aromatase to estrogens. As a result, anastrozole depletes estrogens and can arrest tumor cell growth. Option: B . Cytarabine (also called cytosine arabinoside) is a pyrimidine analog (antimetabolite) that is metabolized to the active moiety, ara-CTP. The ara-CTP becomes incorporated into DNA, with the main ultimate effect being; the suppression of DNA synthesis. It is highly specific for cells in S-phase. Fluorouracil, also an antimetabolite, inhibits thymidylate synthetase. It is not phase-specific, but its activity depends on cells not being in the G0 stage.

questions.text: Which is not an alkylating agent:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fluorouracil (5-FU) Fluorouracil (5-FU) is a cytotoxic chemotherapy medication used to treat cancer. By intravenous injection it is used for the treatment of colorectal cancer, oesophageal cancer, stomach cancer, pancreatic cancer, breast cancer, and cervical cancer.

Highyeild:

Alkylating Agents These compounds produce highly reactive carbonium ion intermediates which transfer alkyl groups to cellular macromolecules by forming covalent bonds. 5-FU is antimetabolite – classified as an anti-pyrimidine compound. Rest all are alkylating agents – act by the formation of active carbonium ion which damages DNA. position 7 of guanine residues in DNA is especially susceptible, but other molecular sites are also involved.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Cyclophosphamide is used in the treatment of different kinds of cancers. It is also used to treat kidney disease known as nephrotic syndrome in children after other treatments have not worked. It may be also used to treat other conditions. Option: B. Chlorambucil is a chemotherapy medication used to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), Hodgkin lymphoma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma. For CLL it is a preferred treatment. It is given by mouth. Common side effects include bone marrow suppression. Option: D. Melphalan is a chemotherapy medication used to treat multiple myeloma, ovarian cancer, melanoma, and AL amyloidosis. It is taken by mouth or by injection into a vein. Common side effects include nausea and bone marrow suppression

Extraedge:

Adverse Effects of Alkylating Agents Myelosuppression is the dose-limiting adverse effect for alkylating agents. Nausea and vomiting are common as are teratogenesis and gonadal atrophy, although in the latter cases these are variable, according to the drug, its schedule, and route of administration. Treatment also carries a major risk of leukemogenesis and carcinogenesis.

questions.text: Topical MITOMYCIN-C Is Used In:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Laryngotracheal Stenosis Laryngotracheal Stenosis refers to abnormal narrowing of the central air passageways. This can occur at the level of the larynx, trachea, carina, or main bronchi. In a small number of patients narrowing may be present in more than one anatomical location.

Highyeild:

Mitomycin is an anti-tumor antibiotic with alkylating agent-like It is used in superficial cancer of the urinary bladder. The drug has radiomimetic effects and also sensitizes hypoxic tumor cells to the effects of hypoxia. Hemolytic uraemic syndrome is a known complication of mitomycin. The drug also produces bone marrow depression. The drug of choice for superficial cancer of the urinary bladder is BCG given intravesically.

Extraedge:

Antifibrotic Property: Anti-fibrotic property of Mitomycin C inhibits (Mitomycin C) Esophaqeaul fibrosis by regulating cell apoptosis and autophagy. The inhibitor of fibroblast into fibrocytes is an important cause of fibrosis.
